Posts.Content: Hi Lucy Thanks you for you're response. Incidentally I'm from Scotland too and I don't know if you're aware that the Scottish government has recently agreed to fund the oncotype test. That aside I'm just hoping the result helps me decide. I'm just not sure if it's worth it with all the side effects of chemo when there are no guarantees it won't come back anyway. However if the percentage falls into the higher level then I probably will take it.  I hope you're doing well Love  Elaine  Xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Thank you Millie 99 X
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn I was a bit like that when it was first suggested and said to the oncologist that I would do anything to prevent it coming back. However looking at the side effects of chemo has made me rethink my decision hence the reason for opting for the test.  I'm just worried that if it's in the mid range that I'll be no further forward with my decision. Anyway 8 days to think about it  Elaine X
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi catchpole Reassuring to read you're experience thank you for that. It feels like it comes down to the opinion of oncologists really. I really think I'd prefer not to and hope that the oncologist can reassure me but so far I'm being told I'm borderline and told the statistics and that it's going to come down me choosing.  My husband would really prefer me to have it as he thinks we should throw everything at it. My daughter is thinking more about the side effects ( she's a student nurse) and is a bit less keen.  I know it has to be my choice but how would I cope with the guilt if I don't have it and it comes back. It's such a dilemma hence why I opted for the oncotype dx test.  Anyway roll on Wednesday. Keep well Elaine X
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hey Dreamthief I thought it was you who originally posted the graph but wasn't sure. Thank you. I I tend having a ball. This is one for the bucket list. Mega excited right now Elaine
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi all I'm newly diagnosed with a stage 2 grade 2 40 mm tumour which is oestrogen positive. I've had 2 operations to remove it all as the first operation hadn't cleared the margins. No lymph node involvement thankfully I met with my oncologist last week who asked me to consider chemo as there's a risk of recurrence. I assumed that I'd just have radiotherapy and hormone therapy. I opted for the oncotype test to try to help me to decide and will get the result next week.  I've read a bit about this now but I'm very undecided as there are no guarantees even with chemo and I'm not sure I want to put myself through it.  I am someone who needs to feel in control of my life and at least I have a choice whether to take it or not. However I think if I was being told that I definitely need it then the decision would be easier.  Has anyone had to make this decision who would like to tell me what influenced their decision please
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Thank you for that dreamthief.   That's kinda where I'm at. I'm worried it comes back in that mid range. In some ways higher or lower makes the decision easier. The graph is very helpful too. Haven't seen it before. I hope you're doing well  Regards Elaine
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Ali 73 Thank you for you're comments and kind words. You're information is very helpful.  Elaine X
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Tarneh Get my results next Wednesday so hoping for a low score. I hate the waiting though.  But par for the course i suppose.  Take care Elaine xxl
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Ann-Marie  You're right this is a fantastic forum and has helped me immensely. I'm very well thank you. My test came back at 19 so my oncologist was happy for me to have radiotherapy and Letrozole and no chemo so that was a great relief as I wasn't sure what I'd have  done had it came back in the mid range so in a way the choice was easy for me.  I completed radiotherapy last week and I'm off to New York tomorrow so all is good. I'm a bit tired and a little sore but otherwise fine. Not sure if you're aware of the scoring system for the oncotype test. Someone on here sent me a diagram but can't remember who but I'm sure it'll be online somewhere. If you can find it I'm sure it'll help. I hope it all goes well for you. However as you may have seen on here from the people who have had chemo, it's all doable.  The waiting for the test is in some ways worse because when you get it at least you then know the way forward in you're treatment. I found the waiting for this test worse than anything else as my head took me to places I didn't want to go. So I empathise with you right now.  I assume, like me ,  you're borderline for chemo and hence the test?? One thing more,  I audiotaped my appts, which helped me to understand/remember all that was said. The oncologist will be fine with that as long as you ask them first,  I'm sure. Hope this helps. Let me know how you get on  Lots of luck  Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra  I dreaded the Mri  but honestly it wasn't too bad. The worse thing is the noise really but you get earplugs and music so it is bearable. Good luck Elaine
Posts.Title: MRI tomorrow! Any advice?

Posts.Content: Great news so pleased for you

My tumour margins were removed to 40mm with clear lymph nodes and oestrogen positive. Currently awaiting the  results of oncotype dx test to decide on treatment options. Really undecided if it comes back in the mid range. Interested in how you got on and what you decided if you don't mind sharing.

Posts.Content: Many happy birthday greetings to you jojo.  Sending you a massive big virtual hug  Elaine Xxx

Posts.Content: Many happy birthday greetings to you jojo.  Sending you a massive big virtual hug  Elaine Xxx
Posts.Title: Birthday

Posts.Content: Glad you're feeling a little better London lass. Take care and good luck in the new year. I hope 2017 is better for you Sending you the gentle hug you always give to others Elaine
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Maisymoo1  He's a keeper. Congratulations to you both and wishing you many happy years together Elaine
Posts.Title: Good News Story for a cold Tuesday

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add to what everyone else has said. I taped my conversations with my oncologists as I am forgetful at the best of times. It helped to listen to it later and was able to take it in better. They usually don't mind as long as you ask them first. Have you any experience of mindfulness.  It might help you to relax a little.  This is the worse part. Once you get you're treatment plan, things tend to settle down. I took about 6 weeks off in total post surgery but worked through radiotherapy but on reduced hours.  My tumour had spread further than they initially thought and I needed further surgery. However I don't think it's obvious to others that my affected boob is  a bit smaller. I've also managed 2 holidays abroad throughout this process which started for me in July.  I suppose what I'm trying to say is that you'll get there girl. I know it's frightening at the moment and it's OK to have a meltdown now and again. I always felt better after a good cry  Sending you positive energy  Elaine
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Done and shared
Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

It helped to listen to it later and was able to take it in better. They usually don't mind as long as you ask them first. However I don't think it's obvious to others that my affected boob is  a bit smaller. It was quite reassuring to listen to it afterward actually.  My onco was happy for me to do this as I asked beforehand. Good luck whatever the outcome Elaine Xx
Posts.Title: possible breast cancer

Posts.Content: So happy for you louby  123. I'm currently awaiting my result but have been told January. Fingers crossed I get good news too Warm regards Elaine
Posts.Title: Gene test result :-)

Posts.Content: Hi kacang  Do you have this on prescription or buy over the counter. I really feel I'd rather take something rather than take my chances with osteoporosis. As we age that's a possibility anyway without the addition of letrozole.. I'm a relatively fit 57 year old and want to ensure continued mobility as long as I can.  Elaine Xx

Posts.Content: Yeah Im thinking it might be worth it for peace of mind if nothing else
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi Berren I think you might be right. A waiting list of 9 months is quite excessive though.  Just something else to worry about
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Very random indeed. I've emailed my BCN today who tells me that this is not standard practice as it is a well woman type investigation rather  than a cancer looking investigation. She said if the doctor had any worries about bone health she would have asked for an urgent one. However good diet should see me OK.  But in 9 months if I do have problems they will put me on a calcium supplement.  Like we hadn't enough to worry about
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi dreamthief That's interesting. I to have been told it could take 9 months for this and I'm on Letrozole.  I'm being treated in Edinburgh. This looks like it's common all over the UK. However I now intend to chase this up and will quote NICE guidelines. Let's see how it goes Elaine
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi there I'm starting mine on 20th October and have followed advice given here by some of the ladies who have recommended a gel and cream called R1 and R2  it's a fairly new skin care regime for radiotherapy burn which is getting good reviews but not routinely given. My oncologist and breast care nurse hadn't even heard of it. Anyway I asked my GP for it who also hadn't heard of it but he looked it up and prescribed it no problem. The pharmacist had to source it from France so I've now got it and am prepared. Maybe you could ask you're GP for it. It's worth a try. If you Google it, you can read what it says about it. Hope it all goes well Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Rads - Panic?

Posts.Content: Hi ladies What a really helpful link this has been. I've not started treatment yet and find the advice on here invaluable so thank you all who have contributed.  Elaine Xx
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Hi misty blue What's that saying " with friends like this " etc etc I hope she never has to deal with anything like this in her life. What an absolute bitch.  You're post made me so angry. I'm afraid if someone, anyone said that to me I wouldn't have been at all polite, and  the second word would have been OFF if you catch my drift. Stay strong girl, you're worth ten of her Hugs Elaine
Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: Love this
Posts.Title: Shoes

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy4u I am also er positive her neg. I started Letrozole 4 weeks ago and rads  tomorrow.no chemo for me.   I believe it depends whether you're pre or post menopausal.  I'm post so hence Letrozole.  However they told me d maybe tamoxifen after 5 years. However research changes things all the time and I guess it'll depend on what's happening then  Good luck whatever you decide Elaine
Posts.Title: ER positive, HER2 Neg. Treatment after Chemo

Posts.Content: Delighted for you xx
Posts.Title: Positive point 6!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Delighted for you Crystal Kitty
Posts.Title: Whoop whoop ... mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hi Glasgow I was diagnosed in July 2016 with a 40 mm invasive lobular cancer. It was her- oestrogen + and progesterone- with clear nodes.  I opted for the test as I was told I was l borderline for chemo. Like moonstar I had 2 lumpectomies 15 rads and now on letrozole. My score was 19 So oncologist felt there would be no more benefit from chemo.  I remember agonising over what I'd do if it came back in the mid range. I had made up my mind that if it was high I'd take it but if in the mid range I just didn't know.  It was such a relief when it came back as it did. It was the longest 2 weeks in the whole process waiting for that result.  I am glad I took the test though because it did help my decision in the end. They initially offered me chemo and because I wasn't sure they offered the oncotype dx test.  So I would say go for it.  Chemo has a lot of side effects and I know everyone is different but for me I was glad I didn't need to face them I hope you manage to reach a decision.  Incidentally Dreamthief's graph helped me to understand the scoring system too Lots of luck Elaine
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi all Been a while since Ive been on here too but had to respond to this.  Ive been on letrozole since October 2016. I ve tried Cipla. Accord and now on Femara which is the most expensive. Initially I had horrendous back pain along with all the other aches and pains. It certainly got better and I was sure at the time it was down to changing the brand. However, I cant really say its been sustained which makes me unsure if there is any difference really. Some mornings I wake and can hardly move. The pain in my hips are awful. I feel so bloody old. I walk a lot which I hope helps but havent really thought abt supplements. Think I might try the anti histamine someone mentioned. I'll try anything because right now I feel  like stopping it altogether.I already personally know three ladies who did this as they couldnt tolerate it. However Im frightened of recurrence so probably wont.  Sorry to moan about all this and I know we are all different.  I suppose my point is that does it really matter what brand we take? I know people say its all about the coatings and fillers but Ive got the rolls royce of brand and it doesnt really make much difference to the aches and pains. Sorry Wendy. Not really helping you. I do hope things settle for you as it seems that many ladies have been ok on i Letrozole Take care Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi Joe It really depends. Did they tell you if you were positive for oestrogen or progesterone and were   you told the grading of you're tumour. I'm also Her 2 - I'm clear of the cancer and will definitely be having hormone and radiotherapy. However because there is a risk it may return I'm considered borderline for chemo so I've opted for an Oncotype DX test (google it) to help.me decide if it's worth having it.  Therefore have had another 2 weeks waiting. It's all very confusing but this forum and the mcmillan website  is very helpful for finding more about treatments et Good luck.  Elaine
Posts.Title: Post Op results

Posts.Content: Hi Adassarose I too am just under 3 weeks post surgery. Are you waiting for the oncotype dx result by any chance? I had lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy then further surgery as the tumour was bigger than first thought. However it wasn't in my lymph nodes thankfully but I too am borderline for chemo. And this test result is due a week today to determine my risk of it returning. At this point it will be my choice whether to have chemo Like you I'm really bored and if my treatment is radiotherapy and hormone therapy, I too plan to get back to work after these results. I hope it all goes well for you Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Post Op results

Posts.Content: I always feel reflective at this time of year and this year is no different yes I've had cancer so it's probably been one of the worst years of my life. I say probably because there have been others. However I've also been fortunate to have a great family who so far have given me the gift of 2 grandchildren who have been my light during this year. Nothing better than a 3 year old throwing her arms around you saying "I love you so much gran ".  My intention next year is to continue my life as I always have. No resolutions  ( always break them anyway). And with a bit of luck remain well and free from cancer.                                                                          So to everyone i say have a happy christmas and a healthy new year. Sending virtual hugs to everyone who has had the good fortune of finding this site. Yes i know we would all have preferred not to have needed to visit but thank the lord for the people on here who give so much help and support despite their own battles Elaine Xxx
Posts.Title: Christmas reflection

Posts.Content: Hi Gacie G I give this advice to everyone I respond to on this forum as it helped me.  I recorded my consultations and was able to actually hear what they were saying as during appts I only took in so much as I was so anxious. I had hubby with me and we both heard different things at times lol. So this helped. All I'll say is to ask if they mind first. Doubt if they will though.  Sending a virtual hig Elaine xx
Posts.Title: CT Scan results -

Posts.Content: Hiya The waiting is awful isn't it. And you change you're mind a thousabd times. Nust wanted to say i lnow how you feel. My score was 19 and my onco supported my drcision of no to chemo.  Do I regret it ? Not so far. There are no guarantees with any of it and I didn't want to go through it all. Rads  were enough thank you very much. Now on letrozole and that'll do me. Good luck whatever you decide.  Elaine
Posts.Title: Help Oncotype result!! Advice please x

Posts.Content: Hi Ange Hopefully youre op is over and youre starting youre recovery. Just wanted to send a very gentle virtual hug Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Big op tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Hi Mandz I remember, just after my diagnosis and before any treatment, the skin on my fingertips all perling off. It was strange. I spoke with my local pharmacist who gave me some cream to soothe it but also said it was probably stress. I think we all react differently really. I started walking more to reduce that and it certainly helped. Good luck in youre ongoing treatment  Elaine xx
Posts.Title: effects....

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar  Just read you're response to London lass. Such wise words. I think you're right. I've went through that whole thing of thinking I should change everything and I think it's because I've been blaming myself for getting this awful illness. But you know what, my life before it was good and I was content. I have always took the path of everything  is OK in moderation and that's the way I mean to go. I've lived 57 years with very little Ill health and hopefully this will be my biggest challenge health wise.  So London lass you go girl anyway you want. Have a lovely Christmas and enjoy life as it is right now
Posts.Title: Am I missing something???

Posts.Content: Hi Misty blue I've always found it helpful to record my conversations with my care providers on my phone as I never took everything in at the time. Just be sure to ask them first if they mind. Mine didn't . Even with my husband with me we both heard different things lol. So it does help Regards Elaine
Posts.Title: What type of breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Misty blue I was diagnosed last July with  invasive lobular cancer which was 4 cm and no lymph nodes involved either. It was also oestrogen +and my treatment was lumpectomy, radiotherapy and Letrozole which inhibits the production of oestrogen, which I'll take for 10 years. .  Wondering why the nurse thinks the surgeon will agree to double mastectomy for you.  I had to have a second operation to take more away as they didn't get clear margins on my first op and remember asking my surgeon if I wouldn't be better with a mastectomy and he says " no I will say when that's necessary if ever"  The second operation successfully removed the cancer and other than a small scar it doesn't look much different from the other.  I suppose I'm just a bit confused as to why you'ld need mastectomy at all.
Posts.Title: What type of breast cancer

Posts.Content: Well done you awesome lady. Time to get you're life back. Good luck in the future Love  Elaine xx
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: Jo Jo 4 I don't like them either. However after boiling slightly I jazz them up by frying with Pancetta and oil and they go down a treat with everyone. ( They keep coming back every year) so can't be bad Have a lovely Christmas Elaine  X
Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Couldn't believe I was reading this as it's almost identical  to my situation. I went to my GP about 18 months before my breast cancer diagnosis  She had me do a few exercises and took blood to check for tumour markers. However everything came back clear and she suggested self referral to physio as she thought it was muscular I didn't bother.!!! Fast forward to my diagnosis which was a 40mm grade 2 tumour, oestrogen + with no lymph spread. Now on Letrozole and I feel it's worse. My pain is in my Hips, lower back and sometimes radiates into my groin. It's also worse at night and when resting.  I'm still able to go to the gym and some days are worse than others. I manage it with ibuprofen and paracetamol. Anyway I decided to bite the bullet and get a consultation with my GP on Tuesday while having my smear test. She ordered an xray of my hips and pelvis and i had that today so waiting the result. I'm driving myself mad, convinced of the worse. However I can rationalise it at times telling myself that there would be other signs,  weight loss etc. The  doc did say it's more likely to be arthritis so the x-ray is to check for signs of that. On a positive note she said downstairs looked healthy lol nice to know I think .  I suppose what I'm saying is. Does this fear ever leave. I try to get on with life and usually can but it's the first thing on my mind as soon as I wake up and I'm sick of it.  Thank the Lord for this network of people who are always here for support. Anyway I've decided if this comes back clear, I'm going to try my damdest  to park the worry. I've so much to look forward to and know others who are worse off Hope all goes well for you  Elaine xx
Posts.Title: really scared about pain in pelvis help and advice please

Posts.Content: Hi snowsy5 mum.  Mr Google has diagnosed me with bursitus  lol. Honestly what are we like. But as so.eone else said on this thread. Never thought I'd be hoping for arthritis rather than what I'm thinking. I will keep in touch to let you know how it goes  They said a week till the result.  Good luck to you Elaine
Posts.Title: really scared about pain in pelvis help and advice please

Posts.Content: Hi adassarose  I'm 3 weeks post rads and have had the cold for 10 days now. Had flu jab so know it's not that. I've hardly slept for coughing and my body so sore, and I can now hardly speak as I'm so hoarse. For someone who generally bounces back from common colds, I'd had enough and phoned my GP surgery , who got the Duty GP to phone me. As soon as I told him my symptoms and recent history they asked me to come in. He said "you've been through so much recently, let's examine you and we can make a decision together on whether I should prescribe Anti biotics " He was lovely and I felt so cared for. The upshot is after examining me I was given Anti biotics as he thinks I have a strep  throat. He said that the rads will have compromised my immunity and this is why I'm struggling to fight it off. So hopefully I'll feel better soon.  He also said if my symptoms get worse I should go straight back.  All I can say is. You know yourself. Don't suffer needlessly,  if it goes on longer than usual see you're GP.   Regards Elaine
Posts.Title: the common cold

Posts.Content: Hi Yogijo  Loving the hairy mclairy reference lol. My BCN advised an electric razor when I told her I was using a razor. I had my last surgery in August and it still feels a weird sensation.even when putting on Deodorant  But the others are right no one expects pristine pits at a time like this. Hope all goes well for you Elaine X
Posts.Title: Armpit shaving!

Posts.Content: Hi Laura I read this and it sounds exactly where I was in July last year. I was 56 too. I too was initially told grade 1 14mm invasive lobular tumour following biopsy and ultrasound.  I had an MRI the following week as is standard. About 5 days later My lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy were done on the same day. I was admitted early morning and taken to the mammography Dept where they insert a wire via ultrasound and local anaesthetic to assist the surgeon in targeting exactly where the tumour is situated. They then did a mammogram to ensure it was situated properly. Later that day I was taken to theatre and the tumour and 3 nodes were removed. I then had a week to see the surgeon again. Unfortunately ( and this is quite common) they didn't get clear margins and my tumour was larger than first thought. It was 40mm and therefore upgraded to a grade 2. I had a further op to remove this but fortunately my lymph nodes were clear. I suppose I'm telling you this to help prepare you're mum as at this point I was totally unprepared as everything up to that point indicated a small area so it was a bit of a shock. However it was all fine with the ops  very bearable. I remember the surgeon saying the MRI wasn't as helpful as it could have been and that it wasn't until the results of my first lumpectomy came back that they realised the extent of the spread.  However I have an oestrogen + progestogen- and herceptin - cancer which apparently is a good one to have as targeted hormone therapies have made a huge difference in recent years.  I was asked to consider chemo as it was progesterone- so was considered borderline. I opted for the oncotype dx test which is a test done in America. They send tissue samples from the tumour to test you're risk of recurrence and again fortunately I had a low score and therefore declined chemo. ( longest 2 weeks of my life ) I then had 15 radiotherapy sessions. Again all doable. Btw if mum has to have this come back on and ask about skin care. Very helpful. I am now on a drug called Letrozole for 5 years which is commonly used in us post menopausal ladies and then possibly tamoxifen for another 5. That will depend on the most up to date research when the time comes. Side effects are bearable mainly. Night sweats and achy joints are the main ones for me. But exercise and diet help. As to you're holiday. Go for it. I had 10 days in Spain between ops and radiotherapy and 5 days in new York a week after radiotherapy.  I hope this helps. Feel I've rambled but I know how much this forum helped me. Please ask anything at all on here. The knowledge is unbelievable as is the support.  Wish you're mum good luck. She'll be fine with a lovely daughter like you by her side. I was lucky to have mine by my side and it helped immensely especially when having my meltdowns Take care Elaine X   I
Posts.Title: Mom diagnosed with invasive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi helsbels  It is just another thing to worry about. I've been invited by my BCN'S to a "What's next" group. So might bring it up then .  Good luck in the future  Elaine
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: Hi helsbels  Like you my 40mm tumour didn't show on mammogram and they weren't even certain of size until first surgery as they thought even after MRI it was smaller than it actually was. I heard the surgeon say to a trainee that the MRI and ultrasound weren't as useful as they had hoped  So like you I really don't have faith in mammogram. I asked my oncologist about it at my second appt with her and she said and I quote "don't worry, we have previous mammograms to compare " which didn't reassure me but did confuse me as I've been having mammograms since I was 45 due to family history. I was 56 at diagnosis.  So surely they already had previous ones to compare with. However I'm not due these until July as only just finished rads 2 weeks ago. I'd be interested in how you get on  Regards Elaine
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Cooper L Did you stop taking these suddenly. They can have terrible side effects which do generally pass after a while but a month of it is quite long to get these. However it's one of the worse ones to stop suddenly and can make you quite Ill depending what you're dose was. Was it 37.5 Mgs  ?? Are you on it for depression or anxiety or both. ?? There are many others you can try as it's not a one size fits all I'm afraid. You're GP should be able to advise.  Hope you feel better soon  Elaine
Posts.Title: Venlafaxine

Posts.Content: Hi Cooper L Sorry you're feeling so bad. It's so awful sometimes. Hopefully the Gabalentin helps. There have certainly been trials done with women with BC  and it seems to be having some success.  Try to keep you're chin Up. It will get better. Sometimes it's a bit of trial and error with people experiencing this side effect of the drugs we take to avoid  recurrence.  Hopefully you'll feel better soon. Sending a wee virtual hug to you ‍xx
Posts.Title: Venlafaxine

Posts.Content: Delighted for you. Onward and upwards now  Elaine
Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi I finished rads early November and shortly after felt awful. Went on for weeks and eventually got antibiotics. The GP told me my immune system would have been compromised by the rads. I also took an allergic reaction to the first antibiotic she gave me. As ive had this one before i couldnt undrrstand it but again she said sgain it was because of my treatment. Since then I seem to pick up everything going. They do say the effect of radiotherapy can last for many years so I assume this is it.  Hope you feel better soon  Elaine
Posts.Title: Hello, I've just joined the forum today and was wondering if anyone...
